results.title: Shape description. Part 1
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”.
The film begins by demonstrating that the only accurate method of telling others exactly how to build an object is to make several drawings showing how the object looks from different points of view. The film then describes orthographic projection, utilising animated diagrams and animated models to provide unusual three-dimensional effects.

results.title: Shape
results.creator_credit: Murray Louis and American Federation of Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Dance”.
The sculptural dynamics of the dancer’s body is the focus of this film. The dancer is revealed as a sculptor who moulds and transforms himself into forms that lend their force to the eloquence of dance.

results.title: Shape
results.creator_credit: Lewis Jacobs and Young America Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Elements of design”.
Discusses shape as one of the basic elements of design, and its function in the art and industry of everyday life. Shows the effects achieved by use of circles, squares, rectangles, triangles, and their various combinations

results.title: Shantiniketan: Abode of Peace
results.creator_credit: Films Division, Government of India, M. Bhavnani, A P Sinha and K Samarth
results.brief_description: In 1901, there was established at Shantiniketan an institution for boys and girls, where education was in close communion with nature. Twenty years later, the institution had grown to such proportions that it came to be recognised as an international university, the Visva-Bharati. This film gives an interesting glimpse of Shantiniketan the “Abode of peace”, the school of international culture, established by the Poet Rabindranath Tagore at Bolpur, not far from Calcutta. Languages, sculpture, painting, embroidery, music, dancing and other fine arts are an integral part of training.

results.title: Shani
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dynamic 18 year old Shani Aziz is a hip hop dancer living in the small town of Maldon where she runs the local fish and chip shop with her mother. She started hip hop dancing with her brother as something fun to do but it has become her passion leading her to start a not-for-profit group to empower young people. She is an inspirational teacher offering the youth of the small Victorian town an outlet for fun and self expression.

results.title: Shanghaied text
results.creator_credit: Ken Kobland, Pierre Bongiovanni, Isabelle Truchot and D1 facilities of the CICV Centre Pierre Shaeffer,Montbeliard/Belfort, France
results.brief_description: In this first part of a projected series on the notion of landscape as ‘artefact,’ images of landscape and industrial history are interwoven and juxtaposed. Notions of ‘civilization’ and ‘progress’ are set against an apparently indifferent nature which continues calm and unchanged in the face of struggle, suffering and wars for dominance. In a radical visual gesture that endows the physical terrain with symbolic content, the land is animated as the theater upon which political struggles have been staged throughout history. Onto austere, seemingly benign landscapes, Kobland superimposes archival footage of peasants in China, revolutionary heroes from early Soviet cinema and footage of Paris during the May ‘68 student riots. Images of the female body from pornography are also projected onto the landscape, eroticizing the land and suggesting both the symbolic colonization of the female body and the notions of the ‘mother country.’ Note: Video Data Bank description: A self-described collage piece’ ofstolen images’ Shanghaied Text starts with quiet Montana landscapes, among which are views of a powerful dam. When the dam breaks loose, you find yourself `shanghaied’ to places unknown, where Kobland confronts you with a provocative mix of historical, lyrical, sexual and political references. Using quotes and pieces from movies by Vertov, Dovjenko and Buñuel, along with archival images of social protests from the liberation of Paris, the piece builds to an operatic culmination with Turandot’s final choir. Shanghaied Text is a remarkable dense and gripping work that leaves the viewer pondering our political and cultural heritage as well as the role of technology in our future.

results.title: Shanghai triad
results.creator_credit: Shanghai Film Studio, Wu Yigong, Jean-Louis Piel and Zhang Yimou
results.brief_description: Set in the 1930s, this film centres on the coming of age of Shuisheng, a country boy brought to Shanghai by his uncle to work for the powerful gang ruled by Tang. He finds himself working for Bijou, Tang’s capricious mistress and nightclub singer. When Shuisheng’s uncle and several other gang members are killed during a rival gang’s unsuccessful attempt on Tang’s life, the latter escapes to a remote island taking both Bijou and Shuisheng with him and thinking of revenge. In Mandarin with English subtitles. Cast includes: Gong Li, Li Baotian, Li Xuejian, Sun Chun and Wang Xiaoxiao.

results.title: Shanghai noon
results.creator_credit: Jackie Chan Films, Spyglass Entertainment, Touchstone Pictures, Gary Barber, Roger Birnbaum, Jonathan Glickman and Tom Dey
results.brief_description: A case of East meets West in this comic adventure Jackie Chan film set in 1850s American West. Chon Wang (Jackie Chan), an Imperial Guard, is sent across to America as part of a rescue team to find the Emperor’s kidnapped daughter, Princess Pei Pei (Lucy Liu). However it is not long before Chon Wang becomes separated from the search party and finds himself lost out in the vast open spaces of the West where he has a timely encounter with a bright but arrogant train robber by the name of Roy O’Bannon (Owen Wilson). The two become unlikely allies. Cast also includes Brandon Merrill, Roger Yuan.

results.title: Shanghai Express
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Adolph Zukor and Josef von Sternberg
results.brief_description: The lightweight plot - an evacuation by train from Peking to Shanghai - is merely the pretext for one of Sternberg’s most successful pieces of stylization, a fruitful collaboration with cinematographer Lee Garmes (and an uncredited James Wong Howe), and writer Jules Furthman. Dietrich plays Shanghai Lily, a ‘coaster’ (a woman who lives by her wits along the Chinese coast) whose scandalous lifestyle is summed up in the films now classic line, ‘It took more than one man to change my name to Shanghai Lily’. Clive Brook’s plays Dietrich’s love interest Captain Donald Harvey, a stuffy Englishman who knew Lily before her infamous lifestyle and is still hurting from her having previously run off on him. Sternberg uses the stop-start cadences of the narrative as a means to evoke the rhythm of the train, while functioning as a kind of time machine confronting the motley group with their pasts as it carries them to their respective fates. However Sternberg’s main point of interest is Dietrich whose status in the film takes on fetishistic proportions, while being gloriously framed and lit in every scene. Cast includes Anna May Wong, Louise Closser Hale, Eugene Pallette, Lawrence Grant. (Awards: Winner, Best Cinematography- Lee Garmes, Academy Awards, 1932)
